DOC.HEAD: Parliament Votes to Change Name, Rewrite Constitution
DOC.TEXT: Parliament voted to change the country's official name Friday and to eliminate the constitutional provision guaranteeing the Communist Party's leading role in the goverment. The constitutional changes were adopted 374-1 with 11 abstentions. The majority of the lawmakers immediately rose and began to sing the national anthem. The move changes the nation's Communist-imposed name, the People's Republic of Poland, to the pre-World War II Republic of Poland. The amendments incorporate into the constitution the reforms won by the Solidarity-led opposition movement, which won partially free elections in June and assumed dominance of the government in August. Soviet-backed Polish communists changed the country's name to the People's Republic of Poland when they proclaimed a new government on July 22, 1944, while the country was still ravaged by war. Both Communist President Wojciech Jaruzelski and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, head of the Solidarity-dominated government, were present for the evening debate on the constitutional amendments. The amendments eliminated the phrase that mandated the leading role of the Communist Party in state affairs and changed a phrase that called Poland a ``socialist society'' to a ``citizens' society.'' The pre-war crown that graced the head of the eagle on the national emblem also was restored. The crown symbolizes Polish sovereignty and unity. The amendments also introduced a provision giving citizens the right to create political parties and other organizations. Until now, the Communist Party, the Democratic Party and the Peasant Party were officially the only legally recognized parties in Poland. Also introduced was a clause guaranteeing protection of private property. The amendments were adopted following a daylong debate, with lawmakers often haggling over one or two words. Earlier, Cardinal Jozef Glemp wished lawmakers strength Friday for the hard tasks ahead. It was the first visit by a Polish primate to Parliament in the country's Communist history. Glemp met with senators and members of all political orientations in the Sejm, as the lower house of Parliament is called, during a midday break in debate over amendments to the constitution and a possible change in the country's national emblem. The lawmakers sang traditional Polish Christmas carols as Glemp entered the building. ``I address all gathered here with great respect and I would like to express my frank, patriotic and hearty wishes,'' Glemp told the lawmakers. ``I wish you enough strength for the coming year and that the link between the nation and the parliament will become stronger and meet with greater understanding. Please accept those best wishes from the church of which I am an abject servant,'' he said. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa used a series of strikes to force the Communists to the bargaining table this year, winning guarantees for a role in the government in exchange for cooperation on Poland's economic problems. But popular support for Solidarity among the masses and repudiation of the Communists forced them to ultimately grant the opposition a dominant role in the government. Reform movements subsequently swept the rest of the East bloc, toppling the old guard Communist governments in Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Bulgaria and Romania.
